TRANSMITTAL OF NOTICE OF APPEAL
I, DeAnna W. Simmons, deputy clerk of the Bankruptcy Court for the Middle District of
Alabama, hereby certify that the documents comprising the notice of appeal are available
electronically by visiting the following link: https://fedcourts.sharepoint.com/sites/ALMB/Shared.
This notice of appeal is transmitted to the clerk of the District Court for the Middle District of
Alabama pursuant to Rule 8003(d), Federal Rules of Bankruptcy Procedure. When you have
accepted the transmittal and downloaded the files, please send an email to
appeals@almb.uscourts.gov acknowledging the transmittal so we can remove the files from the
access point.

1. Notice of Appeal filed on 9/8/25 at DE77

3. Certified Docket Sheet

DeAnna W. Simmons

Case 24-81152 Doc 77 Filed 09/08/25 Entered 09/08/25 14:54:14 Desc Main
Document Page 2 of 2
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 1-2 Filed 09/09/25 Page 1 of 6
UNITED STATES BANKRUPTCY COURT
MIDDLE DISTRICT OF ALABAMA
IN RE Case No. 24-81152-BPC
Chapter 13
CHRISTOPHER BLAINE McGREGOR,
Debtor.
ORDER RECLASSIFYING CLAIM NUMBER 19
This matter is before the Court on Debtor’s Objection to Court Claim Number 19
(the “Objection”). (Doc. 51). This matter is a core proceeding pursuant to 28 U.S.C. §§
157 and 1334. The Court reviewed the pleadings and record, and for reasons set forth
herein OVERRULES the Objection as to timeliness, SUSTAINS the Objection as to
classification, and RECLASSIFIES Claim No. 19 as a general unsecured claim.
I. PROCEDURAL HISTORY AND OVERVIEW OF FACTS
Debtor filed a Chapter 13 petition on September 20, 2024. (Doc. 1). Debtor
scheduled a nonpriority unsecured claim in the amount of $32,000 in favor of his ex-wife,
Brittany Michelle Gilliland (“Creditor”). (Doc. 1, p. 21). The deadline for filings proofs
of claim was November 29, 2024 (the “Bar Date”). (Doc. 7).
On December 2, 2024, Creditor filed Claim No. 19 as a priority unsecured claim in
the amount of $30,000 for a domestic support obligation under 11 U.S.C. § 507(a)(1)(A)
or (a)(1)(B), and, shortly thereafter, amended the claim amount to $32,000 (the “Claim”).
(Claim 19-1; Claim 19-2). Debtor filed the Objection, asserting that the Claim should be
disallowed because it was filed three days after the Bar Date. (Doc. 51). Alternatively,
Debtor argues that, if allowed, the Claim should be treated as a general unsecured claim
because the Claim “is not in the nature of support, [and] therefore not a domestic support
obligation.” Id. In response, Creditor contends that the Claim was timely filed “because
Monday, December 2, 2024, the date Creditor’s Proof of Claim was filed, was the next
business day following November 29, 2024, a state holiday” which is a legal holiday under
Rule 9006(a)(6)(C) of the Federal Rules of Bankruptcy Procedure. (Doc. 52). Creditor
1
Case 24-81152 Doc 73 Filed 09/05/25 Entered 09/05/25 15:38:00 Desc Main
Document Page 1 of 6
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 1-2 Filed 09/09/25 Page 2 of 6
also asserts that the Claim is entitled “to first priority and [is] nondischargeable.”1 (Doc.
52).
II. LEGAL ANALYSIS AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW
This matter requires resolution of two issues. First, the Court must determine
whether the Claim was timely filed under Rule 9006. If the Court determines that the
Claim is untimely, the Court need not address the second issue as the Claim would be
disallowed. If, however, the Claim is deemed timely, the Court must then determine
whether the Claim is entitled to priority status as a domestic support obligation or, instead,
should be classified as a general unsecured claim. A properly filed proof of claim
constitutes prima facie evidence of both the validity and amount of the claim. FED. R.
BANKR. P. 3001(f). Debtor, as the objecting party, bears the initial burden of producing
sufficient evidence to rebut this presumption, thereafter, the ultimate burden of persuasion
shifts back to Creditor. See In re Watson, 606 Fed Appx. 543 (11th Cir. 2015); In re
Barron, 325 B.R. 17, 20 (Bankr. M.D. Ala. 2005).
a. Timeliness of the Claim
Rule 3002(c), together with Rule 9006 and Rule 502(b)(9), generally prohibit the
filing of late claims except under the specific circumstances set forth in Rule 3002(c). Rule
9006(a)(1) governs the computation of time unless a different method is specified. Under
Rule 9006(a)(1), if the last day of the filing period falls on a legal holiday, the deadline is
extended to the next day that is not a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday. FED. R. BANKR.
P. 9006(a)(1)(C). Rule 9006(a)(6) defines a “legal holiday” as:
(A) the day set aside by statute for observing New Year's Day, Birthday of
Martin Luther King Jr., Washington's Birthday, Memorial Day, Juneteenth
National Independence Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Columbus Day,
Veteran's Day, Thanksgiving Day, or Christmas Day;
(B) any day declared a holiday by the President or Congress; and
(C) for periods that are measured after an event, any other day declared a
holiday by the state where the district court is located. (In this rule, “state”
includes the District of Columbia and any United States commonwealth or
territory.)
1 Whether the Claim is nondischargeable is not properly before the Court, and the Court will not address that issue.
2
Case 24-81152 Doc 73 Filed 09/05/25 Entered 09/05/25 15:38:00 Desc Main
Document Page 2 of 6
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 1-2 Filed 09/09/25 Page 3 of 6
FED. R. BANKR. P. 9006(a)(6) (emphasis added). The purpose of Rule 9006(a)(6)(C),
which includes state holidays as “legal holidays,” is to protect against unintended late
filings when a filer might assume courts are closed due to a state holiday. See FED. R.
BANKR. P. 9006, Advisory Comm. Note (2009).
Debtor asserts that the Claim should be disallowed as it was filed three days after
the Bar Date. (Doc. 51, ¶ 5). Creditor argues that the Claim was not untimely as Governor
Ivey “declared November 29, 2024, the day after Thanksgiving, a state holiday.” (Doc.
52). The Governor’s Memorandum, dated May 20, 2024, authorized Thursday, November
28, 2024, and Friday, November 29, 2024, as state holidays. (Creditor’s Ex. 2). Debtor
argues that the Proclamation issued by Governor Ivey designated only November 28, 2024,
not November 29, 2024, as the legal holiday. (Debtor’s Ex. 2). Debtor also cites to Ala.
Code § 1-3-8(a), which delegates to the governor the authority to designate a single day for
Thanksgiving.
Section 1-3-8(a) provides that, in addition to enumerated statutory holidays, “the
day designated by the Governor for public thanksgiving” shall be deemed a legal holiday.
Id. While Debtor is correct that the statute refers to “the day designated by the Governor
for public thanksgiving” in the singular, the statute also authorizes the Governor to
designate additional holidays. ALA. CODE. § 1-3-8(d) (authorizing state banks to close “on
such other days as may be declared by the Governor to be state holidays in honor of a
special event.”) (emphasis added). Governor Ivey’s Memorandum did precisely that by
extending the holiday to include both Thursday, November 28, 2024, and Friday,
November 29, 2024. Thus, November 29, 2024, was a legal holiday under Alabama law.
Accordingly, the Court concludes that November 29, 2024, was a legal holiday
under Rule 9006(a)(6)(C), and the Bar Date was extended to the next business day,
Monday, December 2, 2024. Thus, the Claim is timely.
b. Classification of the Claim
Having determined that the Claim is timely, the Court must next consider whether
the Claim—arising from a monetary obligation imposed by the parties’ Final Decree of
Divorce (the “Divorce Decree”) entered into by the Circuit Court of Tallapoosa County,
3
Case 24-81152 Doc 73 Filed 09/05/25 Entered 09/05/25 15:38:00 Desc Main
Document Page 3 of 6
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 1-2 Filed 09/09/25 Page 4 of 6
Alabama (the “Circuit Court”)—qualifies as a “domestic support obligation” entitled to
priority status under § 507(a)(1)(A) or a general unsecured debt resulting from a division
of property. Under § 101(14A), a “domestic support obligation” refers to a debt, in the
nature of alimony, maintenance, or support, owed to or recoverable by a spouse, former
spouse, child, or governmental unit, arising from a court order, divorce decree, or
separation agreement. 11 U.S.C. § 101(14A). Section 507(a)(1)(A) “provide[s] a priority
claim for domestic support obligations.” In re Hause, 2015 WL 7251662, at *2 (Bankr.
M.D. Fla. Nov. 13, 2015) (internal citation omitted). Unless a divorce-related obligation
qualifies as a “domestic support obligation” under § 101(14A), it does not receive priority
status; instead, it is classified with other general unsecured claims. See Cummings v.
Cummings, 244 F.3d 1263 (11th Cir. 2001).
Whether a debt is a “domestic support obligation” within the meaning of § 101(14A)
is determined under federal bankruptcy law. In re Colin, 546 B.R. 455, 458 (Bankr. M.D.
Ala. 2016) (citing Cummings, 244 F.3d at 1265). Yet “state law provides guidance in
determining whether an obligation should be considered ‘support[.]’” Id. (internal citations
omitted). Because “it is likely that neither the parties nor the divorce court contemplated
the effect of a subsequent bankruptcy when the obligation arose[,]” courts must look
beyond labels and examine the substance of the obligation rather than its form to determine
whether the debt is in the nature of support or alimony. Cummings, 244 F.3d at 1265
(internal citations omitted); see also In re Colin, 546 B.R. at 458; In re Saggus, 528 B.R.
452, 457 (Bankr. M.D. Ala. 2015). When deciding whether an obligation is in the nature
of support or alimony, a bankruptcy court must consider the intent of the parties or the
divorce court, as reflected in a settlement agreement or divorce judgment. Cummings, 244
F.3d at 1266; see also In re Santry, 481 B.R. 824, 829 (Bankr. N.D. Ga. 2012) (noting that
“the intentions of the divorce court or, if a settlement, the parties when the obligation was
created are of primary importance” in determining whether a debt owed is in the nature of
support). Here, the Divorce Decree does not incorporate a marital settlement agreement
by the parties and there was no evidence offered to support that the terms of the Divorce
Decree were the result of a consensual agreement between the parties. As a result, the
4
Case 24-81152 Doc 73 Filed 09/05/25 Entered 09/05/25 15:38:00 Desc Main
Document Page 4 of 6
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 1-2 Filed 09/09/25 Page 5 of 6
Court finds that the language of the Divorce Decree best reflects the intentions of the
Circuit Court. See Cummings, 244 F.3d at 1266.
Looking to the language of the Divorce Decree, Paragraph 7 provides that Debtor is
to pay Creditor the sum of $51,411.21 (the “Obligation”), representing “one-half (1/2) of
the equity in the residence[.]” (Doc. 52, Ex. 1, at ¶ 7) (emphasis added). Debtor could
satisfy the Obligation by either paying an initial $10,000 lump sum within ten days of the
entry of the Divorce Decree followed by twenty-one monthly installments of $2,000, or by
making a lump-sum payment in full within ninety days. Id. Once the Obligation is paid in
full, Creditor is obligated to execute a “Quit Claim Deed” transferring her interest in the
residence to Debtor. (Doc. 52, Ex. 1, at ¶ 6). Thus, the Obligation is complete upon
payment in full by Debtor and not upon any contingency, such as remarriage by Creditor.
The Divorce Decree also provides a remedy in the event of nonpayment of the
Obligation by Debtor—specifically, sale of the residence and equal division of the
proceeds. (Doc. 52, Ex. 1, at ¶ 7). The Divorce Decree does not authorize enforcement
through contempt, permit modification, or describe the Obligation in terms typically
associated with support. In re Davison, 2014 WL 6674770, at *3 (Bankr. M.D. Ala. Nov.
24, 2014) (“Under Alabama state law, alimony is modifiable, but a property settlement in
a divorce is not modifiable.”).
Additionally, the Divorce Decree expressly states that “[n]either party is ordered to
pay alimony.” (Doc. 52, Ex. 1, at ¶ 23). Unlike attributes of support, the language in
Paragraph 7 sets forth a reciprocal exchange: Creditor receives a fixed sum representing
her share of the equity in the residence, and in return, she must relinquish her interest in
the residence upon full payment of the Obligation. Id. The amount is precisely calculated
based on the value and equity in the residence, and it is not based on any assessment of
Creditor’s financial needs. Further, there is no suggestion in the Divorce Decree that the
Obligation was intended to provide for Creditor’s living expenses or subsistence. At the
evidentiary hearing, Creditor testified that she relied on the monthly payments to meet her
financial obligations. However, Creditor’s post hoc reliance does not control the
classification. Moreover, the Divorce Decree separately provides for child support to be
5
Case 24-81152 Doc 73 Filed 09/05/25 Entered 09/05/25 15:38:00 Desc Main
Document Page 5 of 6
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 1-2 Filed 09/09/25 Page 6 of 6
paid by Creditor to Debtor—suggesting that any obligation of support ran in the opposite
direction. (Doc. 52, Ex. 1, at ¶ 16). Lastly, it is also persuasive that the Divorce Decree
allocated all remaining debts and assets to the individual parties, severing any ongoing
financial interdependence. Id., at ¶¶ 19–20.
Here, there is no indication in the Divorce Decree that the Circuit Court intended
the Obligation to function as support for Creditor. Accordingly, the Court concludes that
the Obligation is not a domestic support obligation, but a property settlement; thus, the
Claim is not entitled to priority treatment.
III. CONCLUSION
For the reasons set forth herein, the Court OVERRULES the Objection as to
timeliness, SUSTAINS the Objection as to classification, and RECLASSIFIES the Claim
as a general unsecured claim.
Done this 5th day of September, 2025.
Bess M. Parrish Creswell
U nited States Bankruptcy Judge
c:
Debtor
Charles M. Ingrum, Jr., Attorney for Debtor
Algert S. Agricola, Jr., Attorney for Creditor
C hapter 13 Trustee
